page.title: 12Shabbington Woods-Oakley
page.content: Shabbington Woods form part of the Bernwode Forest. It is mainly coniferous with some young oaks.Coniferous forests yield softwood timber,while the young oak (known as broad leaved trees) will eventually give us hard woods.The wood has a natural meadow within it which is very rich in wild flowers,grasses and butterflies.In the woods there are lookout-towers for fires and deer,and also clearways known as rides,these help to prevent fire spreading also the trees are thinned out continually to give light to the forest and to prevent overcrowding.The Oxford Way walk passes the woods, and Menmarsh point is on the boundary line.There is a local tale that somebody was hanged in the woods.
